description: From Latin āvocātiō (“a distraction”), from āvocō (“I call off, distract”).

entries.meaning: A hobby or recreational or leisure pursuit.
examples: But yield who will to their separation,
My object in living is to unite
As my two eyes make one in sight.

entries.meaning: That which calls one away from one's regular employment or vocation.
Pursuits; duties; affairs which occupy one's time; usual employment; vocation.
examples: I have several things on the anvil, and near finished, that perhaps might be useful, if published: but the continual avocation by business, the impositions on me by impertinent visits, and the uneasiness of writing, which grows more intolerable to me every day, I doubt, will prevent my going any farther.

entries.meaning: The calling of a case from an inferior to a superior court.
